headline.main: After Food Sellers Restock, Customers Get Their Chance

docs.abstract: New Yorkers return to supermarkets, delis and restaurants after blackout, but are skeptical of freshness of food; stores throw away thousands of dollars worth of spoiled food (L)
docs.snippet: Dorene Howard held the package of chicken gizzards up to her nose and sniffed.    ''What do you think?'' she asked her friend Curtis Aiken, shoving the shrink-wrapped package under his nose. ''Are these O.K.?''

byline.original: By LYDIA POLGREEN and COLIN MOYNIHAN

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Mary Crownover saw a flier for a program called MediSavers that advertised savings of up to 80 percent on medical care and prescription drugs, for a one-time broker fee of $29, she thought it was too good to pass up. It was late 2001 and Ms. Crownover was uninsured and more than a year away from qualifying for Medicare. Her MediSavers card sat in her wallet until one evening last April, when chest pains sent her to the hospital emergency room near her home in St. Charles, Mo. She presented her card and then spent the night undergoing tests at the hospital. Doctors ultimately gave Ms. Crownover a clean bill of health, but then came the bill, for $5,061.80. So what kind of savings did she get from her card? Just $278, around 5 percent of the invoice. ''I was shocked,'' said Ms. Crownover, now 65. Every procedure she said she saw on the company Web site showed a savings of at least 56 percent.

headline.main: Some Health Discounts May Be No Bargain

docs.lead_paragraph: Thirty-one years ago, Idi Amin embarked on a campaign to remove Asians from this country. He expropriated their homes and businesses. He called them bloodsuckers. As they trooped to the airport and crowded the highways, his soldiers robbed them along the way. Now, with Mr. Amin's reign of terror long over, there are strong signs of an Asian revival here. Many, although not most, of the Asians that Mr. Amin expelled have picked up their lives in Uganda again. Their role in the country's economy rivals the influence they had in the 1970's that so infuriated the dictator.

headline.main: Once Outcasts, Asians Again Drive Uganda's Economy

docs.abstract: Thousands of Asians of mostly Indian origin, who were expelled from Uganda in 1972, have returned in large numbers, operating businesses as they have done since Indian laborers were brought in by British to build railway; Asians represent less than one percent of population but play huge role in economy, as they did when their dominance so infuriated Idi Amin (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AUGUST in South Texas, with temperatures soaring above 100 degrees and the humidity forming a dew that simmers on the mesquite brush, is not the easiest time for cowboys on the King Ranch. On such days, the tools of modern ranching, like air-conditioned pickups and helicopters used to shoo cattle, help only so much. ''There's no good explanation for why we do this work,'' said Joey Salazar, 34, a leathery fifth-generation kineño, as the residents and employees born on the legendary 825,000-acre ranch call themselves. ''I was born on this ranch, and I expect to die on it,'' Mr. Salazar, sweat-drenched and clad in chaps and boots with spurs, added in Spanish while taking a break from castrating a group of young calves.

headline.main: Betting the Ranch, a Really Big One

docs.abstract: King Ranch Inc is betting its future on areas unrelated to cattle, from leasing land to quail hunters to lending ranch's name to line of luxurious pickup trucks; challenges facing ranch include claim by descendants of Maj William W Chapman, business partner of Richard King when ranch was formed in 1850's, to 7,500 key acres at ranch's core; another pressing issue is how to keep ranch's large cattle herd relevant in age of skepticism about beef eating; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: LIKE many new college graduates, Kellie Lee was thrilled when she finally got a serious job. It was actually her dream job, a position as an admissions counselor at an acting school and career center in Longwood, Fla. ''The owner had the most wonderful spirit,'' said Ms. Lee, 23, who lives in Orlando.

headline.main: For Many, Full-Time Work Means Part-Time Benefits

docs.abstract: Growing numbers of job applicants find that positions with health, retirement and other benefits are scarce; many young college graduates--and even some older workers wishing to make career changes--are taking jobs without health insurance or retirement plans because they cannot find anything with more security (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT is exactly the kind of annoyance that I've endured perhaps 100 times in dozens of different theaters: a cellphone ringing away in someone's pocket just as a show gets going. Except, in this case, it was my cellphone. In my pocket. And I wasn't in the audience; I was onstage.

headline.main: The Actor's Life for Me, Fringewise

docs.abstract: Jesse McKinley article recounts his monthlong experiment in immersion journalism/acting when he took role as actor, working his way through rehearsal process to appearing on stage, in play Cats Talk Back at Kraine Theater as part of New York International Fringe Festival; photos (L)
